items.title: Recording single neurons at scale in the primate brain
items.author: Frank F. Lanfranchi
items.content: In this Tools of the Trade article, Frank F. Lanfranchi describes Neuropixels 1.0 NHP, which allows the tracking of co-ordinated activity of hundreds of neurons across different brain areas in non-human primates, revealing the complexity of neural dynamics during complex tasks.

items.title: Affective tactile comfort: is a specialized sensory system involved?
items.author: Takayuki Yamashita
items.content: In this Journal Club, Takayuki Yamashita discusses a 2002 study about the role of unmyelinated C-tactile afferents in touch.

items.title: Climate change matters to neuroscience
items.author: Sanjay M. Sisodiya
items.content: Neuroscientists must engage with climate change now because its effects on their research are and will continue to be widespread and because neuroscience itself is a contributor to climate change. As evidence-driven, ethically concerned scientists, we have important roles to play in tackling this global challenge to health and wellbeing.

items.title: A neural compass for real-world navigation
items.author: Katherine Whalley
items.content: Head-direction cells act as a stable ‘neural compass’ as bats navigate across a large natural outdoor environment.

items.title: The evolutionary origins of synaptic proteins and their changing roles in different organisms across evolution
items.author: Pawel Burkhardt
items.content: Recent studies have shed further light on the evolutionary origins of chemical synapses, In this Review, Colgren and Burkhardt explore how ancient proteins were co-opted into functional assemblies and propose events that gave rise to true synapses from early sensory-secretory cells.

items.title: The neural circuits and signalling pathways of opioid use disorder
items.author: Emmanuel Darcq
items.content: In many parts of the world, opioid use disorder presents a growing challenge to public health, reinforcing the need to decipher its underlying mechanisms. Mathis et al. provide an overview of our current understanding of the neural circuits and molecular signalling pathways involved in the transition from opioid use to opioid use disorder.

items.title: Facial expressions reveal inner cognitive processes
items.author: Katherine Whalley
items.content: The facial movements of mice provide a noninvasive readout of the 'hidden' cognitive processes taking place during decision-making.

items.title: Central neural circuits underlying itch sensation
items.author: Yan-Gang Sun
items.content: Itch has an important role as a somatosensory defensive mechanism. In this Review, Sun synthesizes CNS circuits underlying itch signal processing and its modulation in the spinal cord, transmission of processed itch information to the brain for encoding, and evoked sensory and affective components from the perception of itch.
